description: It is common knowledge in the construction industry that there is a growing shortage of skilled labor in the workforce, with senior workers retiring faster than they can be replaced. Now, with the rise of COVID-19, the absence of skilled labor is even more likely in the immediate future. To serve as an example, Stephen B. Jacobs Group took advantage of modular design...
text:
It is common knowledge in the construction industry that there is a growing
shortage of skilled labor in the workforce, with senior workers retiring
faster than they can be replaced. Now, with the rise of COVID-19, the absence
of skilled labor is even more likely in the immediate future. With this in
mind, it s no wonder that modular construction is becoming one of the most
popular trends to discuss when planning a new project.

To break it down, modular construction involves creating buildings from a
series of modules that are crafted in a factory setting. Similar to cruise
ships or submarines, the individual modules are transported to construction
sites for assembly. Because most of the building is not being constructed on
location, the assembly process for a modular-designed building moves quicker
and with less skilled labor than a typical construction project.

To serve as an example, Stephen B. Jacobs Group took advantage of modular
design and construction for one of our more recent projects, the citizenM
Bowery hotel. Currently the world s tallest modular hotel, citizenM Bowery was
largely developed using factory built modules which simplified on-sight
construction and expedited the overall process. The typical citizenM guest
room was conceived as a module and most of the brand s hotels around the world
are build using modular construction.

Modular construction is especially well suited for short span spaces such as
guest rooms, and less for long span spaces such as lobbies and lounges. For
that reason, the citizenM Bowery Hotel was designed using three different
structural systems. The lower floors, up to the fourth-floor slab, were built
conventionally, using poured-in-place concrete. The 15 typical modular guest
room floors were then stacked on top of the 36-inch fourth floor concrete
slab. And finally, above the modules, the rooftop bar, outdoor terrace, and
additional mechanical spaces were built using conventional steel construction.

Building the world s tallest modular hotel within the dense urban fabric of
New York City s Lower East Side was not without logistical challenges. But we
overcame all these challenges and proved that building using modular
construction make sense even on difficult sites.

Stephen B. Jacobs Group are currently working on several affordable housing
projects outside of New York City using wood modular construction. These
projects are two to three stories and are logistically much easier to build,
given the open space. These projects are another example of types which make
total sense to build using modular construction.

Healthcare facilities are another project type that can benefit from modular
construction. Especially now during the COVID-19 pandemic, additional
facilities could be quickly and efficiently built using factory build modular
construction.

Modular construction will continue to grow as a construction type, especially
in the hospitality, healthcare, and affordable housing markets. The scarcity
of skilled labor and the efficiency of building in a factory-controlled
environment make modular construction a no brainer. And the more modular
projects are designed and built, the more efficient the process will become.

About Isaac-Daniel Astrachan, AIA, LEED AP: Principal Mr. Astrachan has been
with Stephen B. Jacobs Group since 1998 where he started as the project
manager for the Hotel Giraffe. Since then he has worked on the design of most
of the firm s projects including the Hotel Gansevoort in the Meatpacking
District, 325 Fifth Avenue, The Ohm, the Copper Building, The Edge, Gansevoort
Park Avenue Hotel, and ALTA LIC. He recently completed the citizenM Bowery
Hotel, the world s tallest modular hotel, and is currently working on a five-
star boutique hotel in Tribeca.

Prior to joining the firm, Mr. Astrachan worked for Didier Repellin, Chief
Architect and Inspector-General of historic monuments in France.

Isaac-Daniel Astrachan graduated from Columbia College in 1990 and received
his Master of Architecture degree from Harvard s Graduate School of Design in
1995. Originally from the village of Gordes in the south of France and
Detroit, Michigan, Mr. Astrachan currently resides in Battery Park City with
his wife and son. He serves on the board of Downtown United Soccer Club, is a
member of Pier 40 Champions, and is on the Executive Committee of the Hudson
River Park Advisory Council.

About Stephen B. Jacobs Group: Stephen B. Jacobs Group, PC/Andi Pepper
Interior Design is a full service architectural and interior design firm
founded in 1967. Over the years, they have completed a wide range of
commissions, including high-rise condominiums, international hotels, boutique
hotels, office buildings, and adaptive reuse and preservation projects. In
many commissions, the firm has provided turn-key services, including
architecture and interior design. The combination of architects and interior
designers working together under one roof from day one facilitates a seamless
integration of the two disciplines. The work of the firm has been extensively
published and has won numerous awards for its design excellence.

keywords.text: Harvard s Graduate School of Design

title: Combating a Shortage of Skilled Labor with Modular Construction
html:
It is common knowledge in the construction industry that there is a growing shortage of skilled labor in the workforce, with senior workers retiring faster than they can be replaced. Now, with the rise of COVID-19, the absence of skilled labor is even more likely in the immediate future. With this in mind, it s no wonder that modular construction is becoming one of the most popular trends to discuss when planning a new project.

To break it down, modular construction involves creating buildings from a series of modules that are crafted in a factory setting. Similar to cruise ships or submarines, the individual modules are transported to construction sites for assembly. Because most of the building is not being constructed on location, the assembly process for a modular-designed building moves quicker and with less skilled labor than a typical construction project.

To serve as an example, Stephen B. Jacobs Group took advantage of modular design and construction for one of our more recent projects, the citizenM Bowery hotel. Currently the world s tallest modular hotel, citizenM Bowery was largely developed using factory built modules which simplified on-sight construction and expedited the overall process. The typical citizenM guest room was conceived as a module and most of the brand s hotels around the world are build using modular construction.

Modular construction is especially well suited for short span spaces such as guest rooms, and less for long span spaces such as lobbies and lounges. For that reason, the citizenM Bowery Hotel was designed using three different structural systems. The lower floors, up to the fourth-floor slab, were built conventionally, using poured-in-place concrete. The 15 typical modular guest room floors were then stacked on top of the 36-inch fourth floor concrete slab. And finally, above the modules, the rooftop bar, outdoor terrace, and additional mechanical spaces were built using conventional steel construction.

Building the world s tallest modular hotel within the dense urban fabric of New York City s Lower East Side was not without logistical challenges. But we overcame all these challenges and proved that building using modular construction make sense even on difficult sites.

Stephen B. Jacobs Group are currently working on several affordable housing projects outside of New York City using wood modular construction. These projects are two to three stories and are logistically much easier to build, given the open space. These projects are another example of types which make total sense to build using modular construction.

Healthcare facilities are another project type that can benefit from modular construction. Especially now during the COVID-19 pandemic, additional facilities could be quickly and efficiently built using factory build modular construction.

Modular construction will continue to grow as a construction type, especially in the hospitality, healthcare, and affordable housing markets. The scarcity of skilled labor and the efficiency of building in a factory-controlled environment make modular construction a no brainer. And the more modular projects are designed and built, the more efficient the process will become.

About Isaac-Daniel Astrachan, AIA, LEED AP: Principal Mr. Astrachan has been with Stephen B. Jacobs Group since 1998 where he started as the project manager for the Hotel Giraffe. Since then he has worked on the design of most of the firm s projects including the Hotel Gansevoort in the Meatpacking District, 325 Fifth Avenue, The Ohm, the Copper Building, The Edge, Gansevoort Park Avenue Hotel, and ALTA LIC. He recently completed the citizenM Bowery Hotel, the world s tallest modular hotel, and is currently working on a five-star boutique hotel in Tribeca.

Prior to joining the firm, Mr. Astrachan worked for Didier Repellin, Chief Architect and Inspector-General of historic monuments in France.

Isaac-Daniel Astrachan graduated from Columbia College in 1990 and received his Master of Architecture degree from Harvard s Graduate School of Design in 1995. Originally from the village of Gordes in the south of France and Detroit, Michigan, Mr. Astrachan currently resides in Battery Park City with his wife and son. He serves on the board of Downtown United Soccer Club, is a member of Pier 40 Champions, and is on the Executive Committee of the Hudson River Park Advisory Council.

About Stephen B. Jacobs Group: Stephen B. Jacobs Group, PC/Andi Pepper Interior Design is a full service architectural and interior design firm founded in 1967. Over the years, they have completed a wide range of commissions, including high-rise condominiums, international hotels, boutique hotels, office buildings, and adaptive reuse and preservation projects. In many commissions, the firm has provided turn-key services, including architecture and interior design. The combination of architects and interior designers working together under one roof from day one facilitates a seamless integration of the two disciplines. The work of the firm has been extensively published and has won numerous awards for its design excellence.
